question: A.01 [1.0 point] What is β?

answers.answer: a. The fractional change in neutron population per generation
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE: DOE Fundamentals Handbook Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory, Volume 2, Module 4

answers.answer: b. The fraction of all fission neutrons that are born as delayed neutrons
answers.feedback: Correct. REFERENCE: DOE Fundamentals Handbook Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory, Volume 2, Module 4

answers.answer: c. The time required for the reactor to change by power by a factor of e
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE: DOE Fundamentals Handbook Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory, Volume 2, Module 4

answers.answer: d. The fraction of all delayed neutrons that reach thermal energy
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE: DOE Fundamentals Handbook Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory, Volume 2, Module 4

question: A.02 [1.0 point] Which ONE of the following is the expected stable neutron count rate given a source strength of 300 neutrons per second (N/sec) and a multiplication factor of 0.5?

answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE: CR = S / (1 - k) → 300 / (1 - 0.5) = 600 N/sec
Incorrect. REFERENCE: CR = S / (1 - k) → 300 / (1 - 0.5) = 600 N/sec
Incorrect. REFERENCE: CR = S / (1 - k) → 300 / (1 - 0.5) = 600 N/sec
Correct. REFERENCE: CR = S / (1 - k) → 300 / (1 - 0.5) = 600 N/sec

question: A.03 [1.0 point] Which ONE of the following conditions will DECREASE the reactor core excess?

answers.feedback: Correct. REFERENCE: NRC standard question
Incorrect. REFERENCE: NRC standard question

answers.answer: c. Insertion of a positive reactivity worth experiment
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE: NRC standard question

answers.answer: d. Lowering moderator temperature (assume negative temperature coefficient)
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE: NRC standard question

question: A.04 [1.0 point] What are the two common FISSION PRODUCTS that have especially large neutron cross sections and play a significant role in reactor physics?

answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE: Burn, Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, Section 8.1, Page 8-1
Incorrect. REFERENCE: Burn, Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, Section 8.1, Page 8-1
Incorrect. REFERENCE: Burn, Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, Section 8.1, Page 8-1
Correct. REFERENCE: Burn, Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, Section 8.1, Page 8-1

question: A.05 [1.0 point] What is the corresponding aTmod given a moderator temperature INCREASE of 7°F, the worth of the regulating rod is 0.001 Δk/k/inch, and the regulating rod drives in 3.5 inches to compensate?

answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE: 0.001 Δk/k / (7°F / 3.5 inches) = 0.001 / 2 = 0.0005 = 5 x 10^-4 Δk/k/°F
Incorrect. REFERENCE: 0.001 Δk/k / (7°F / 3.5 inches) = 0.001 / 2 = 0.0005 = 5 x 10^-4 Δk/k/°F
Incorrect. REFERENCE: 0.001 Δk/k / (7°F / 3.5 inches) = 0.001 / 2 = 0.0005 = 5 x 10^-4 Δk/k/°F
Correct. REFERENCE: 0.001 Δk/k / (7°F / 3.5 inches) = 0.001 / 2 = 0.0005 = 5 x 10^-4 Δk/k/°F

question: A.06 [1.0 point] Which ONE of the following statements correctly describes the reason for operating a reactor with thermal neutrons instead of fast neutrons?

answers.answer: a. The fission cross section of the fuel is much higher for fast neutrons than thermal energy neutrons. Since fast neutrons are easier to cause fission, a reactor cannot control with fast neutrons
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE: Burn, Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, Figure 2.6, Page 2-39

answers.answer: b. The neutron lifetime of thermal neutrons is longer than fast neutrons, so the fuel has enough time to capture thermal neutrons
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE: Burn, Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, Figure 2.6, Page 2-39

answers.answer: c. The fission cross section of the fuel is much higher for thermal energy neutrons than fast neutrons, so thermal neutrons are easier to cause fission
answers.feedback: Correct. REFERENCE: Burn, Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, Figure 2.6, Page 2-39

answers.answer: d. The atomic weight of thermal neutrons is larger than fast neutrons, so thermal neutrons are easily to slow down and be captured by the fuel
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE: Burn, Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, Figure 2.6, Page 2-39

question: A.07 [1.0 point] Which ONE of the following describes the general shape in determining the integral rod worth of a control rod?

answers.answer: a. Parabolic shaped, with the maximum at the top and bottom of the core height
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE: Reed Training Manual, Chapter 10.3, Figure 10.6

answers.answer: b. S-shaped, with the net change in reactivity from bottom to top
answers.feedback: Correct. REFERENCE: Reed Training Manual, Chapter 10.3, Figure 10.6

answers.answer: c. Cosine shaped, with the largest change in the middle of the core height
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE: Reed Training Manual, Chapter 10.3, Figure 10.6

answers.answer: d. Exponentially shaped, with the maximum at the bottom of the core height
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE: Reed Training Manual, Chapter 10.3, Figure 10.6

question: A.08 [1.0 point] Which ONE of the following is a correct statement of how delayed neutrons enhance the ability to control reactor power?

answers.answer: a. Prompt neutrons can cause fissions in both U-235 and U-238 and delayed neutrons can only cause fissions in U-235
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE: Burn, Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, Section 3.3.2, Page 3-7

answers.answer: b. Delayed neutrons increase the average neutron lifetime that allows a reactor to be controlled
answers.feedback: Correct. REFERENCE: Burn, Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, Section 3.3.2, Page 3-7

answers.answer: c. The average number of delayed neutrons produced per fission is higher than the average number of prompt neutrons
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE: Burn, Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, Section 3.3.2, Page 3-7

answers.answer: d. Delayed neutrons are born at higher energy levels than prompt neutrons
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE: Burn, Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, Section 3.3.2, Page 3-7

question: A.09 [1.0 point] Which factors of the six factor formula are affected by an INCREASE in core temperature and how are they affected? L_f - Fast non-leakage probability, L_t - Thermal non-leakage probability, ε - Fast fission factor, p - Resonance escape probability, η - Thermal fission factor, f - Thermal utilization factor

answers.feedback: Correct. REFERENCE: DOE Fundamentals Handbook Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory, Volume 2, Module 1
Incorrect. REFERENCE: DOE Fundamentals Handbook Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory, Volume 2, Module 1
Incorrect. REFERENCE: DOE Fundamentals Handbook Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory, Volume 2, Module 1
Incorrect. REFERENCE: DOE Fundamentals Handbook Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory, Volume 2, Module 1

question: A.10 [1.0 point, 0.25 each] Match the following Neutron term in Column A with the appropriate definition in Column B (each used only once)

answers.answer: a. Delayed Neutron - 3. Neutron born due to decay of a fission product
answers.feedback: Correct. REFERENCE: DOE Fundamentals Handbook Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory, Volume 1, Module 2, Pages 29-37

answers.answer: b. Fast Neutron - 4. Neutron at an energy level greater than its surroundings
answers.feedback: Correct. REFERENCE: DOE Fundamentals Handbook Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory, Volume 1, Module 2, Pages 29-37

answers.answer: c. Thermal Neutron - 2. Neutron in equilibrium with its surroundings
answers.feedback: Correct. REFERENCE: DOE Fundamentals Handbook Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory, Volume 1, Module 2, Pages 29-37

answers.answer: d. Prompt Neutron - 1. Neutron born directly from fission
answers.feedback: Correct. REFERENCE: DOE Fundamentals Handbook Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory, Volume 1, Module 2, Pages 29-37

Correct. REFERENCE: DOE Fundamentals Handbook Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory, Volume 2, Module 3, Page 35

question: A.12 [1.0 point] Which ONE of the following is the MAJOR source of heat released after shutdown?

answers.answer: a. Production of prompt gamma rays
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE: Burn, Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, Section 4.10.14, Page 4-33
Incorrect. REFERENCE: Burn, Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, Section 4.10.14, Page 4-33
Correct. REFERENCE: Burn, Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, Section 4.10.14, Page 4-33
Incorrect. REFERENCE: Burn, Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, Section 4.10.14, Page 4-33

question: A.13 [1.0 point] A subcritical reactor, k_eff is increased from 0.924 to 0.987. Which ONE of the following is the amount of reactivity that was added to the core?

answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE: Burn, Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, Section 3.3.4, Page 3-20&21 Δp = (k_eff2 - k_eff1) / (k_eff1 * k_eff2) = (0.987 - 0.924) / (0.987 * 0.924) = 0.0690 Δk/k or 6.9% Δk/k

Correct. REFERENCE: Burn, Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, Section 3.3.4, Page 3-20&21 Δp = (k_eff2 - k_eff1) / (k_eff1 * k_eff2) = (0.987 - 0.924) / (0.987 * 0.924) = 0.0690 Δk/k or 6.9% Δk/k

Incorrect. REFERENCE: Burn, Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, Section 3.3.4, Page 3-20&21 Δp = (k_eff2 - k_eff1) / (k_eff1 * k_eff2) = (0.987 - 0.924) / (0.987 * 0.924) = 0.0690 Δk/k or 6.9% Δk/k

Incorrect. REFERENCE: Burn, Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, Section 3.3.4, Page 3-20&21 Δp = (k_eff2 - k_eff1) / (k_eff1 * k_eff2) = (0.987 - 0.924) / (0.987 * 0.924) = 0.0690 Δk/k or 6.9% Δk/k

question: A.14 [1.0 point] Reactor is critical. What would be the corresponding k_eff when removing 5% Δk/k from its criticality?
A.15 [1.0 point] Which ONE of the following power changes will take the LONGEST time to complete? Assume the reactor is on a CONSTANT positive period.

answers.feedback: Correct. REFERENCE: P = P_0 e^(t/T) → t = T * ln(P/P_0) assume constant period = 1. The smallest ratio of P/P_0 is the shortest time to complete
Incorrect. REFERENCE: P = P_0 e^(t/T) → t = T * ln(P/P_0) assume constant period = 1. The smallest ratio of P/P_0 is the shortest time to complete
Incorrect. REFERENCE: P = P_0 e^(t/T) → t = T * ln(P/P_0) assume constant period = 1. The smallest ratio of P/P_0 is the shortest time to complete
Incorrect. REFERENCE: P = P_0 e^(t/T) → t = T * ln(P/P_0) assume constant period = 1. The smallest ratio of P/P_0 is the shortest time to complete

question: A.16 [1.0 point] Which ONE of the following conditions would INCREASE the shutdown margin of a reactor?

answers.answer: a. Inserting an experiment adding positive reactivity
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE: Burn, Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, Section 6.2.3
Correct. REFERENCE: Burn, Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, Section 6.2.3

answers.answer: c. Depletion of a burnable poison
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE: Burn, Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, Section 6.2.3

answers.answer: d. Lowering moderator temperature if the moderator temperature coefficient is negative
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE: Burn, Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, Section 6.2.3

question: A.17 [1.0 point] Which ONE of the following best describes the difference between reflectors and moderators?

answers.answer: a. Reflectors decrease thermal leakage while moderators decrease fast leakage
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE: Burn, Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, Section 5.4

answers.answer: b. Reflectors thermalize neutrons while moderators decrease core leakage
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE: Burn, Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, Section 5.4

answers.answer: c. Reflectors decrease core leakage while moderators thermalize neutrons
answers.feedback: Correct. REFERENCE: Burn, Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, Section 5.4

answers.answer: d. Reflectors shield against neutrons while moderators decrease core leakage
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE: Burn, Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, Section 5.4

question: A.18 [1.0 point] How high will the reactor power get given the following: the lowest of the reactor high power scram set points is 120%, the scram delay time is 0.5 seconds, the reactor is operating at 100% power prior to the scram, and the reactor period is positive 20 second?

answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE: P / P_0 = 120%, T = 20 seconds, t = 0.5, P / P_0 = 120 e^(0.5 / 20) = 123%
Incorrect. REFERENCE: P / P_0 = 120%, T = 20 seconds, t = 0.5, P / P_0 = 120 e^(0.5 / 20) = 123%
Correct. REFERENCE: P / P_0 = 120%, T = 20 seconds, t = 0.5, P / P_0 = 120 e^(0.5 / 20) = 123%
Incorrect. REFERENCE: P / P_0 = 120%, T = 20 seconds, t = 0.5, P / P_0 = 120 e^(0.5 / 20) = 123%
